["vote", {"voter": "geoffrey", "weight": 10000, "permlink": "its-been-a-while-", "author": "peachesdoe97"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2580540, "timestamp": "2016-06-23T05:58:06", "id": "2.17.404775", "trx_id": "39f35b8e719f8311a3e7052dc25f0b0417b11253", "virtual_op": 12532}]], [[11, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "how-to-purchase-anime-figures-not-readily-available-outside-of-japan", "parent_author": "", "title": "How to purchase anime figures not readily available outside of Japan", "body": "![Miku fan](https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/4b/cf/21/4bcf2164bbd20738f16d604d842c733d.jpg)\n\n## Choosing a Figure\nSo you've decided that you really like a particular anime, or Japanese video game, or perhaps even, potentially, a popular movie made in the west, such as Tim Burton's \"The Nightmare Before Christmas,\" and would like to know which figures exist for it. The easiest way of finding out is going to http://myfigurecollection.net/ and searching for the title of the show, or the name of a specific character you are interested in. From there you can select a listed figure and read reviews for it. Reviews are helpful because the quality of figures is not consistent across manufacturers. You may also want to search by the show or character name written in Japanese on these various websites if you can't find too many options. This information is available for a plethora of anime on http://en.wikipedia.org or http://myanimelist.net\n\n## Comparing Prices\nNow that you have your figure selected, you will want to shop around to see what your options are. You should keep the *My Figure Collection* tab open, and start going through this list in a new tab. If a JAN number is listed for your figure, that should be your first search term. If that yields no results, than search by the name of the figure, the name of the character, or the name of the series. \n\nA large portion of the final cost will be dedicated to shipping expense. EMS is the default method due to its terrific speed, and only slight increase in cost over the significantly slower options, and also includes insurance. This should be kept in mind though, and if possible figure purchases should be bundled together to reduce shipping costs overall. Whichever site has your figure, and the most other figures you also desire should be the one you order from.\n\n## Figure Retailers\n* Auction Sites:\n * http://www.ebay.com/\n * http://auctions.yahoo.co.jp/ (May require Japanese address)\n* Shopping Portals:\n * http://www.amazon.com/\n * http://www.amazon.co.jp/ (Shipping may be prohibitively expensive (or blocked))\n * http://global.rakuten.con/en\n * http://www.rakuten.co.jp/ (These listings can also be obtained by setting Global Rakuten's search results to be in Japan (Shipping may be blocked))\n* Overseas Friendly Retailers:\n * http://amiami.com/ (Most of their inventory is for currently running shows)\n * http://www.jlist.com/home\n * http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/\n * http://ekizo.mandarake.co.jp/shop/en/\n\n## Ordering Process\nOnce you have chosen all of your figures and are ready to check-out, try entering your address and see if the website accepts it. If not, you will have to use a forwarding service. That will be covered in the next section. Before being charged, most websites require you to wait a period of a day or two for them to calculate shipping charges. You will need to enter payment info before this, but are not charged until they get your approval for the final shipping charges. If paypal is accepted, that is generally your best option for payment method, though credit card may be easier if you don't have a paypal account. Transaction fees in converting your currency to JPY have to be considered, since the majority of these services require payment in Yen.\n\n## Currency Conversion\nMost credit cards have a low fee on foreign transactions, between 1-3%. Some cards, however, have a 0% fee. These include all Capital One cards, Discover Card, and many air-travel branded cards. Check your credit card terms under the fee section to make sure before using a particular card. If you don't have a credit card, or your credit card has a >2% fee, you should use the paypal currency conversion \u201cfeature\u201d. This feature is turned on by default when you are about to check-out through paypal, and is not clearly indicated. They do charge a fee, so make sure you go through the \u201cselect your payment method\u201d options to find the \u201callow my credit card processor to do the currency conversion\u201d option. Paypal will warn you this will involve a fee, but if you use the above mentioned credit cards it will not.\n\nYou may wish to check on https://www.google.com/search?q=yen+conversion+rate or a similar conversion service to determine how much to expect your final bill to be. There's a delay between your authorizing the payment, and it actually being charged, so the final credit card charge may vary.\n\n## Forwarding Services\nRecently a few options have popped-up for ordering from website that don't ship overseas. You need to create an account on a forwarding service, and they will give you an address to mail your purchases. Depending on the service, you may need to inform them to expect a package, or they may even need to place the order for you. Keep in mind that you will have to not only pay for the item and shipping to you, but also shipping to the forwarding service, as well as a forwarding service fee, making this an expensive option often, but usually not as expensive as just buying the item from an e-bay seller. Some options include:\n\n* http://www.fromjapan.co.jp/\n* http://www.tenso.com/en/\n* http://biginjap.com/content/16-forwarding-terms (Also a retailer)\n* http://www.japantodoor.com\n\n## Final Notes\nNow that you are an expert in ordering figures, you may want to plan your purchases in advance. Figures that aren't out yet are generally cheaper than after they are released, so you may want to use one of the retailers to pre-order for all of the series you are excited about. Some popular figures sell out within a day of pre-orders, anyway, so to get the really rare ones this is the best option.\n\n**Has this article convinced you to get into figure collecting? Feel free to list any questions in the comments, and I'll try my best to answer them!**\n\n*Disclaimer: The author (geoffrey) wrote this piece in 2013, so some website may have gone offline, and better options may have came into existence. Corrections to the article posted in the comments by astute readers will be incorporated into the text. Thanks!. http://reddit.com/r/animefigures is a great contemporary resource for news on upcoming figures and opinions on merchants, manufacturers, return policies, etc.*", "author": "geoffrey", "parent_permlink": "anime", "json_metadata": "{\"tags\":[\"anime\"],\"image\":[\"https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/4b/cf/21/4bcf2164bbd20738f16d604d842c733d.jpg\"]}"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2604735, "timestamp": "2016-06-24T02:09:24", "id": "2.17.410878", "trx_id": "1831ca56628a31a97c80ea0f4f30150093e887ec", "virtual_op": 18748}]], [[12, {"op": ["vote", {"voter": "geoffrey", "weight": 1000, "permlink": "how-to-purchase-anime-figures-not-readily-available-outside-of-japan", "author": "geoffrey"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 1, "block": 2604735, "timestamp": "2016-06-24T02:09:24", "id": "2.17.410879", "trx_id": "1831ca56628a31a97c80ea0f4f30150093e887ec", "virtual_op": 18749}]], [[13, {"op": ["vote", {"voter": "hipster", "weight": 10000, "permlink": "how-to-purchase-anime-figures-not-readily-available-outside-of-japan", "author": "geoffrey"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2604745, "timestamp": "2016-06-24T02:09:54", "id": "2.17.410880", "trx_id": "2f1c2808926985c5612671cc53d1a199e91ab315", "virtual_op": 18750}]], [[14, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "re-kenny-crane-re-shawn-murphy-623-free-bitcoin-daily-updated-faucet-list-and-some-altcoin-faucets-20160624t021521124z", "parent_author": "kenny-crane", "title": "", "body": "Hi Kenny,\n\nI haven't tried any of these listed sites, or any faucet in the past 3 years, but my general experience has been that the rewards they offer are no where near worthy compensation for your time. In return for filling out captchas or watching 30 seconds of an ad, you get maybe 1/1000th of a cent of BTC or some altcoin; not worth the effort by **any** standard!\n\nWhile they could potentially be useful for learning to play with an altcoin you have 0 of, they generally require an accumulation of enough value to \"withdraw\", meaning visitng the faucet 10's to 100's of times in order to get paid once, and still seeing maybe 1 collective cent of value. Don't get me wrong, this isn't done out of malace, but in order to offset the transaction fee, and to overcome the minimum transaction size, the faucet can't just pay out a decent amount on one visit without costing the person running it more than they profit from the ads. There may be some faucets ran to promote a new altcoin in this fashion, so those I don't discourage you from trying out, if you can manage to find one.\n\nThere are also android apps with faucets, such as \"free bitcoin\", but I can't promise they're not malware. I'm Geoffrey!", "body": "Thank you for having me, I'm really excited to be here!\n\nI first got into cryptos weeks before the bubble in 2013, where it went from ~$20 to $240 in about 3 months, and 3 months later was back down to $70. I'm a very cautious investor, so my investment totaled approximately 0.01 BTC at the time. Pretty funny how these things go. Nevertheless, it was an exciting time, to say the least!\n\nEarly on in my exploration in the crypto space, Primecoin (XPM) was announced. This new Altcoin opened up my mind to the possibility of using massively distributed computational power to both extend our scientific understanding, while simultaneously enriching the personal wealth of those who believe in the mission statement of such a coin enough to devote mining power to it, or to encourage others to do so by purchasing said coin on an exchange.\n\nSubsequent to that, I was equally excited about Riecoin (RIC), a competing currency based on solving a different problem set. The unique possibilities were unraveling at my feet. \n\nAnyway, three years have gone by since then, and cryptocoins haven't launched the scientific-crytpocurrency revolution I was hoping for. Similar altruistic projects, such as one based on paying people to compete in Folding@home never went anywhere. The coins I mentioned don't have nearly the market cap of the meme-coins and well promoted pre-mined-coins, but despite that there's still hope.\n\nI believe that the core concept of incentivizing contribution to society lives on in projects such as this very platform! And through the level of abstraction and simplification, they've made that goal accessible to the layman without requiring hours of research into wallet clients and mining algorithms, or to spend money on fancy single-function mining equipment . By allowing viewers to rate content, and paying the content creators based on their ratings, Steem is another step on the path I was hopeful for.\n\nSo to return to my initial statement, I'm excited at the potential of Steem, and hope it will encourage development of more altruistic endeavors in the crypto-space. I personally plan to write more to help provide quality content accessible through the platform. I've already taken my first step with an updated version of an article I wrote for DevCoin, another \"dead\" crypto that could be seen as the progenitor of this service in some ways, but with nowhere near the same level of comprehensive development. You can see that article here: https://steemit.com/anime/@geoffrey/how-to-purchase-anime-figures-not-readily-available-outside-of-japan and I hope to be writing many more in the "2.17.438255", "trx_id": "7f555f3c530c9572e5c3a866bab5e99c62028719", "virtual_op": 46326}]], [[73, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "a-primer-on-british-tv-shows-from-an-american-s-perspective", "parent_author": "", "title": "A Primer on British TV Shows From An American's Perspective", "body": "![Union Jack](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Union_flag_tv.svg)\n\nWith the turbulence caused by Brexit calming down, and American Independence Day being tomorrow, it feels like a good time to celebrate Great Britain's notable contributions to global media. What follows are some of the TV shows I've thoroughly enjoyed which come from the UK. This list is by no means exhaustive, in fact even a casual viewer probably has heard of the majority of them. Nevertheless, if you're looking for something to watch and haven't seen one of them, they're worth checking out.\n\nThis list is roughly sorted by popularity, and is not ranked based on my or anyone's opinion of the quality of the shows. Any show on this list comes with my highest recommendation.\n\n\n# 1. Doctor Who\n![logo](http://vignette2.wikia.nocookie.net/tardis/images/6/69/Doctor_Who_Logo_without_BBC.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20111006032934)\nI don't imagine there are many people left who haven't heard of this series. While it originally started in the 1960's, the show was recently rebooted by Russell T Davies in 2005, after which it really caught on in the States. The popularity of the show owes to its blend of soft science fiction, adventure, and wit. Originally intended to be a family show, it's still quite approachable for all ages. While on initial viewing some of the predominant antagonists will definitely seem extremely cheesy or campy, this is done deliberately as an homage to the show's original run's pre-CG, low-budget, roots. To really enjoy Dr. Who you definitely have to suspend your disbelief and just enjoy the ride-along through space and time with The Doctor in the Tardis.\n\n\n# 2. Top Gear\n![logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/84/REALTopGearLogo.png)\nAnother extremely popular reboot from a bygone era, Top Gear is an exploration of automobiles and car-culture. The appeal of the show is mainly in the dynamic of the three announcers: Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond, and James May. The real highlight of the show are the episodes in which they go on journeys together, e.g., to Vietnam or some of our southern States. Much of the camera work on the car test drives done with perfectly matched background music is blissful eye-candy. \n\nOver the years the show has become less about honest reviews of the various high-end vehicles they get to race around their track, and more about annoying producers and teasing each other. It makes the show enjoyable, but loses it some credibility with the \"petrolhead\" crowd. The presently airing series has a different line-up due to an incident with Jaremy Clarkson that forced the BBC to fire him, so I can't comment on the quality of the currently running show, but series 1-22 are definitely worth checking out!\n\n\n# 3. Misfits\n![logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/40/MisfitsIntertitle.png)\nA dark comedy about teens who are forced to do community service developing super hero powers. The Misfits classlessly addresses a lot of issues relevant to angsty teens. Most of the original cast is gone by the 4th season, marking a shift in the appeal of the show. Personally I felt it was still worth watching all the way through. Despite the show being focused on the activities of delinquents, to me it demonstrates that people innately desire to be good, all they need is nurturing.\n\n\n# 4. IT Crowd\n![logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/The_IT_Crowd_title_card.jpg)\nThis often quoted on Reddit sitcom is about the adventures of two underappreciated IT workers and their computer-illiterate boss. The show only had four 6-episode seasons, and a special movie released sometime later. While it takes a few episodes to acclimate to the strange tone and pacing of the show, it becomes hilarious and certain events will stick in your memory for months after you finish watching it.\n\n\n# 5. Peaky Blinders\n![logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/e8/Peaky_Blinders_titlecard.jpg)\nThis period-piece (set shortly after World War 1) crime drama is about a local gang and the man who turns it into something great through hard work and perseverance. In slight modification of the standard formula, the show features a present-day soundtrack featuring mostly rock music. Despite being anachronistic, it fits with the show's tone quite well, and adds to its character. The third season just finished airing, but unfortunately I felt it was less invigorating than the previous seasons. Watching a criminal enterprise being built from the ground up in the first two seasons is somehow much more enjoyable than watching it maintain its status.\n\n\n#6. Spaced\n![logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/10/Spaced.jpg)\nA sitcom created by Simon Pegg and Edgar Wright from Shaun of the Dead fame, along with female lead Jessica Stevenson. The show concerns two 20-somethings who move in together to save money. Although in the standard sitcom format, and with only two seasons, the show is extremely entertaining, and has developed a cult-following in the States and elsewhere.\n\n\n#7. Elizabeth R\n![logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/d7/ElizabethR3.jpg)\nFilmed in 1971, this show is quite different from everything else on this list. Being set in Elizabethan times, however, means that this period piece feels completely current. I stumbled on this drama, based on the history of Elizabeth I, after finishing The Tudors on Showtime and wanting to see what became of the heirs of Henry VIII. Despite having 90 minute episodes, the time just flies by watching this show as the tense Shakespearean drama unfolds. Set up like a play, the acting is the focus of this show, and it is performed brilliantly by the whole cast.\n\n\nFeel free to give your impression of these shows, or other recommendations in the comments! \"And On That Bombshell, Goodnight!\"", "author": "geoffrey", "parent_permlink": "tv", "json_metadata": "{\"tags\":[\"tv\"],\"image\":[\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Union_flag_tv.svg\"]}"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2883441, "timestamp": "2016-07-03T19:20:27", "id": "2.17.475359", "trx_id": "d9138e6061ccc365bc92dbec0998377a52d0b901", "virtual_op": 18092}]], [[74, {"op": ["vote", {"voter": "geoffrey", "weight": 10000, "permlink": "a-primer-on-british-tv-shows-from-an-american-s-perspective", "author": "geoffrey"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 1, "block": 2883441, "timestamp": "2016-07-03T19:20:27", "id": "2.17.475360", "trx_id": "d9138e6061ccc365bc92dbec0998377a52d0b901", "virtual_op": 18093}]], [[75, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "re-svk-bitshares-gui-release-2-0-160702-20160703t194437517z", "parent_author": "svk", "title": "", "body": "Is it possible for the wallet to auto-update, or at least inform the user of a new release?", "author": "geoffrey", "parent_permlink": "bitshares-gui-release-2-0-160702", "json_metadata": "{\"tags\":[\"bitshares\"]}"}], "trx_in_block": 1, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2883921, "timestamp": "2016-07-03T19:44:27", "id": "2.17.475623", "trx_id": "e2979282484ab470cdfc15c5d3c28f7c0bd92d6a", "virtual_op": 18359}]], [[76, {"op": ["vote", {"voter": "geoffrey", "weight": 10000, "permlink": "re-svk-bitshares-gui-release-2-0-160702-20160703t194437517z", "author": "geoffrey"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2883925, "timestamp": "2016-07-03T19:44:39", "id": "2.17.475625", "trx_id": "5e824aa26a56c2f8ee11de377ac730fa85cefecf", "virtual_op": 18361}]], [[77, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "re-svk-bitshares-gui-release-2-0-160702-20160703t194638431z", "parent_author": "svk", "title": "", "body": "The link for the binary is missing the \"v\" in the version number, so it gives a 404 error. property is called \"memorylessness\". In this specific case, where we are describing the timing of events in a Poisson process, knowing the timing of one event doesn't give you any information about the timing of the next event (they are independent events). I hope someone found that aside informative, and I'd love to expand on it for anyone curious.", "author": "geoffrey", "parent_permlink": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000", "virtual_op": 38992}]], [[95, {"op": ["vote", {"voter": "fractalnode", "weight": 10000, "permlink": "re-svk-bitshares-gui-release-2-0-160702-20160703t194437517z", "author": "geoffrey"}], "trx_in_block": 1, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 2958041, "timestamp": "2016-07-06T10:18:42", "id": "2.17.600188", "trx_id": "023cf2e2e4623a3285e8a720fd93f6649b7fd375", "virtual_op": 12241}]], [[96, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "evidence-of-an-efficient-market-in-bitcoin-or-why-halving-the-reward-won-t-suddenly-cause-the-price-to-double", "parent_author": "", "title": "Evidence of an efficient market in Bitcoin, or why Halving the reward won't suddenly cause the price to double", "body": "\n

There's understandably a lot of excitement about the mining reward for Bitcoin halving tomorrow.  The direct implication of this is that the cost of mining a Bitcoin will double between two blocks.  While it's easy to imagine the cost of a single Bitcoin will double, to compensate those hard working miners, the past, and economic theory, have shown that this is extremely unlikely to be the case.  I will proceed to show some analysis I have done supporting the claim that the effect of the halving on price will be minor, and has already occurred.
\n


\n

Evidence of an efficient market in Bitcoin
\n

What is shown here is a scatter plot of daily values of the percent change in the closing price of Bitcoin over the past 6 years.  While the x-value indicates the change from the day before, the y-value indicates that day's change for each point.  What is immediately noticeable is that there is no obvious trend, there seem to be roughly an equal number of points in each quadrant, with concentric circles of concentration that increase closer to the origin.  If the market behaved as some of us would like, there would mostly be a trend of larger x-values corresponding to larger y-values.  This would indicate that when yesterday the price went up a lot, the price will most likely go up again the next day.  Of course that's not realistic, and no such behavior is observed, at least at the time-scale measured.
\n

\n

I have plotted a linear fit across all points, that is, the line which best explains the underlying trend in the data, assuming a linear relationship between two-day price changes, and the presence of zero-mean Gaussian-distributed noise.  What is immediately noticeable is how \"flat\" the line looks.  There is no clear relationship between yesterday's change in price, and today's.  This is supported by the extremely small R^2 value of 0.0028, suggesting a very weak correlation between these two-day change in prices.  Interestingly, this trend is significant (p < 0.05), but I believe it can be explained by the general trend of Bitcoin price to increase over time, as awareness and adoption increase.
\n

The implication of these results is clear: the effects of any big event, such as a positive news story or a popular new service, are instantly priced in, and do not take a period of days to impact the price level of Bitcoin.  This is, basically, the efficient market hypothesis.  This effect also implies that the 'Halving' is already priced in.  If it weren't, it would be possible to buy up massive amounts of coins before the halving, in order to sell them afterward at a profit.  Because the halving is common knowledge, you wouldn't be the only person with this idea.  Because so many others may have the same idea, the price would necessarily increase to the level that those same people feel it will be worth after the halving.  Thus, after the halving occurs, there will be no large price change observed (absent the general wide variability of Bitcoin prices).  What this all means, in the short-term, is that there's no way to take advantage of a known event's effect on the price of Bitcoin, because that effect will disappear as a result of efforts to do so.
\n


\n

The first Halving
\n

In further support of this, I've plotted the price level, and price change, of Bitcoin the month before and after the first 'Halving', which occurred on 11/28/2012.  The claims I have made based on the previous result are supported here.  Despite the large noise in daily prices, and the general upward trend in prices (perhaps due to increased adoption and excitement in the community), there is no solid price increase immediately subsequent to the halving.  I see no reason why things should be different this time around.
\n

\n


\n

Conclusion
\n

I'm sorry to put a damper on your 'Halving Day' celebrations, but I don't want anyone to risk more than they can afford to lose in the hope that the reward halving will make them rich.  I encourage you, the reader, to dispute any of my claims, and suggest other analysis that may bring different effects to light.
\n


\n

Data source: http://www.coindesk.com/price/, analysis tools: Microsoft Excel.
\n

This article is an extension of a Reddit post made by the author on /r/BitcoinMarkets.
\n


\n

"three-anime-recomendatios-this-season", "author": "nkdk"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 3136079, "timestamp": "2016-07-12T15:12:18", "id": "2.17.803302", "trx_id": "3eec1e68a2366a4baa5d94630985d191074820eb", "virtual_op": 21178}]], [[122, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "how-to-build-good-credit", "parent_author": "", "title": "How to build good credit", "body": "\n

\n


\n

While it's common knowledge that a person's credit score can affect their ability to get a good rate on a loan for a car, to start a small business, or to get a mortgage, the specifics of what goes on the credit reports that those rates are based on are unfortunately misunderstood by many.
\n


\n
How your credit score is determined
\n

There are three main reporting agencies, all of whom track the same information concerning your credit-worthiness.  The credit score itself is determined by a formula weighing different information provided by the credit reports supplied by these companies.  The implicit implication of this is that, depending on which credit report a financial institution \"pulls\" in order to determine your eligibility and rates for a loan, they could assign you a drastically different score.  This is an uncommon scenario, however, since ideally all credit reports will contain the same information.
\n


\n
Factors affecting your credit score
\n

The key to understanding your credit score is to keep in mind that only what is on one of your credit reports can influence it.  The specifics of how that information is weighted and penalized varies over time and with the credit scoring agency, but the factors are constant since they are only what's included in your credit report.  
\n

Here's a list of those financial factors, roughly in order of importance:
\n

    \n
    Derogatory Marks \n
        \n
        Do you have unpaid bills or loan payments from more than 60 days ago?
        \n \n
    \n
    Payment History\n
        \n
        How many of your bills have you paid on time?  
        \n
        This can include every month's payment for every line of credit for the life of each line of credit
        \n \n
    \n
    Credit Card Utilization \n
        \n
        Do you max out your cards?  This is a bad idea for an additional reason: Credit card interest rates are obscene
        \n \n
    \n
    Age of Credit History (How many years have you had each line of credit open (Longer is better)
    \n
    Credit Inquiries\n
        \n
        How many lines of credit have you applied for in the past 1-2 years\n
            \n
             Depends on reporting agency
            \n \n
        \n \n
    \n
    Total Accounts (slightly redundant since age of credit contains this information, but not weighed very heavily)
    \n
    SSN, current and previous addresses, (self-reported) employer. (None of these factors affect credit scores)
    \n

\n

And that's it!
\n


\n
Factors not affecting your credit score
\n

The good thing about credit reports is, though misunderstood, they are very democratic.  They don't enable judging a person's credit-worthiness based on their skin color, ethnicity, political-leanings, etc.  All that they allow banks to use to determine a person's credit worthiness is their history of credit interactions.  Though there is an implicit inclusion of a person's age, i.e., the older you are the more easily you could have had lines of credit for 10+ years, which helps a lot.
\n

\n
Implication of factors affecting credit
\n

Again, because most people don't even realize what's on their credit report, there's a lot of misinformation swirling around about how to improve your credit.  As you can see from the list of factors, there are certain aspects you can focus on improving, some of them not at all intuitive, that will improve your credit score tremendously.  I have distilled the combination of factors into bits of advice, depending on your situation, that can allow you to increase your credit score, over the course of a few years, up to 850, a \"perfect score\" (with the  VantageScore 3.0 scoring system).
\n

\n
How to take advantage of your new understanding of the credit report
\n

I have separated the advice into a few categories of people.  Choose the one(s) which best match your situation.
\n

    \n
    You have outstanding debt which is in collections\n
        \n
        Believe it or not, before I understood how credit reports works, this was me!  Now I have a score of >800, so there's clearly hope if you're in credit despair over this
        \n
        Advice:\n
            \n
            Pay off your debt!
            \n
            Make sure to tell your debtors to report to the credit reporting agencies that your debt was paid in full
            \n
            Write letters to each reporting agency disputing that the debt should no longer be listed on your credit report (They don't like to remove things without being prompted)
            \n
            You can still get credit cards with automated online systems, if you apply
            \n
               Even in the case where you owe money, having more lines of credit will help you in the long run
            \n \n
        \n \n
    \n

\n


\n

    \n
    You only have a few credit cards\n
        \n
        There's a limit on how high your score can go, even if you've had your cards for a long time, and pay them off every month
        \n
        Advice:\n
            \n
            Open lots of credit cards!  More on this in General Advice
            \n \n
        \n \n
    \n

\n


\n

    \n
    You have a high balance on a credit card\n
        \n
        Open a card with an offer to transfer your debt, and take advantage of that offer!\n
            \n
            You'll save a ridiculous amount in interest for a year, eighteen months, or two years
            \n
            You'll have a larger \"available credit\" which directly decreases your credit utilization, improving your score immediately
            \n
            You'll have another card, increasing your total lines of credit
            \n \n
        \n \n
    \n

\n


\n

    \n
    General Advice\n
        \n
        Open lots of credit cards!  \n
            \n
            You should be applying for 2~3 every year, until you have at least one with every big bank (Citibank, Chase, Capital One, Discover, American Express, Barclay's, Credit Unions, etc. (be creative in looking for credit cards)
            \n
            Though you can wait for a good bonus offer.  If you're desperate for credit I'd say $150 is good, but generally you'll want $300+ sign up bonus (though they do require heavy spending in the first 6 months)
            \n \n
        \n
        Close credit cards with annual fees before you've had them for a year\n
            \n
            These people are called card-churners and banks hate them, but the credit report doesn't indicate that you are one of them
            \n
            They generally do it for the enrollment bonuses, but recently banks have cracked down on them by only allowing a person one enrollment bonus in their lifetime
            \n
            Believe it or not, closing new accounts will increase your average length of credit, improving your score!  Pretty dumb how they encourage churners, right?
            \n
            If you only have a few open accounts, however, that can be detrimental to your score
            \n \n
        \n
        Pay off your bills every month!\n
            \n
            While CC utilization of >1% helps, beyond that it only hurts!  Stop paying off this predatory lending you don't actually need!
            \n \n
        \n
        Check your credit reports for errors, or inefficiencies in your activity\n
            \n
            Should you be opening more lines of credit?  If you have less than 15, then yes
            \n
            Have you missed any payments?  You should pay them off right away
            \n \n
        \n \n
    \n

\n


\n
How to check your credit report
\n

Due to the raising trend in identity theft, there's something called a Fair-credit reporting act.  Just search for one of the three credit reporting agencies Equifax, TransUnion, or Experian and \"FCRA request\" and you can get a free and full credit report once a year (or whenever a credit request gets denied).  Check it for errors!  Better yet, pull all three, and check all three for errors!  If you're in a rush, many credit card companies now offer you a monthly peak at your score.  At least knowing this will suggest which premium credit cards you are able to reasonably apply for.
\n


\n
Closing comments
\n

I hope this article has helped you develop an understanding of how to build credit!  If there's further interest, I can write a follow-up on specific credit card deals, situational advantages of specific card products, the difference between \"soft-pulls\" and \"hard-pulls\", credit freezes and how they can help you, how to spend reward points, moralistic gray-areas for improving your access to credit, or similar advice.
\n

"steem-is-now-the-5th-largest-crypto-by-market-cap", "parent_author": "", "title": "Steem is now the 5th largest crypto by market cap!", "body": "\n\nAccording to Coin Market Cap, only hours ago, Steem has overtaken The DAO to be the #5 ranked crypto by market cap (Coins in circulation x Price per coin). This puts Steem (Mcap = $139M) on equal footing with Litecoin (Mcap = $195M) and Ripple (Mcap = $232M).\n\nThis represents an increase in price from just yesterday of 125%! And yesterday saw similar gains over the day before!\n\nThere's only so far a crypto can climb in such a short period, so it's unlikely for Steem to surpass Litecoin, at least not this week. It's also possible we're seeing a flash-bubble, so be careful investing in it now.\n\nThis is only on $500k in trading in the past 24-hrs, so I'd advise extreme caution. The system of trapping Steem Power in the ecosystem causes hysteresis. Over the period of upcoming weeks we may see people trying to cash-out, lowering the market cap considerably, but in a smoother fashion than is seen with other crypto-bubbles.\n\nSource: https://coinmarketcap.com/\n\n*Disclaimer: This article is original Steemit content.\n\n

"re-mianeri-what-power-down-means-in-steem-20160714t003943744z", "parent_author": "mianeri", "title": "", "body": "Power down: convert Steem Power to Steem.\nPower up: reverse\n\nConverting: Steem Power cannot be traded. It is gained indirectly from people upvoting your posts, agreeing with posts you upvoted, and holding steem power in your account. To trade it for other coins, or money, you need to \"power down\".\n\nMore on powering down: You don't immediately get Steem for your Steem Power, it takes 2 YEARS! Every few days you'll get a portion of the Steem Power you powered down as Steem, which you can then trade. You get 1 Steem for every 1 Steem Power you \"power down\"\n\nMarket: You can also trade Steem Dollars for Steem to power up, or trade it directly for BTC or whatever, but not directly on "77.798278 VESTS", "comment_permlink": "trespassing-waterfalls-and-giant-centipedes", "curator": "geoffrey", "comment_author": "heiditravels"}], "trx_in_block": 4, "op_in_trx": 1, "block": 3388659, "comment_permlink": "steemit-s-first-professional-hockey-player", "curator": "geoffrey", "comment_author": "thebear"}], "trx_in_block": 6, "op_in_trx": 1, "block": 3392709, "timestamp": "2016-07-21T16:18:21", "id": "2.17.1719093", "trx_id": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000", "virtual_op": 33165}]], [[1121, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "tor-a-brief-introduction-to-the-anonymous-web", "parent_author": "", "title": "TOR - A Brief Introduction to the Anonymous Web", "body": "

\n\n# Motivation\n\nThe existence of Tor network is well known in tech circles. What exactly it is, how it works, and its limitations are not always correctly understood or conveyed within these circles, however. The goal of this article is to endow the reader with a superficial understanding of the Tor network. If nothing else, I hope you walk away from reading this article with an appreciation of why an onion is an apt symbol for Tor.\n\n

\n\n# How to get started using Tor\n\nIf you've already heard of Tor, but don't know how to get started using it, the easiest way is to just download the browser bundle, launch it, and start browsing the web at this link. If you're familiar with Mozilla Firefox, you'll feel right at home using the Tor browser. The two most basic concepts of the Tor network to understand are what using this specific browser accomplishes. \n\n\n\nUsing the browser gives you access to both the dark web, and the clear web, whose properties are enumerated here:\n\n1. The clear web:\n * Going to any normal URL which could be accessed directly in a standard web browser still works on the Tor network.\n * This web page access will be hobbled, however, due to the delay from your traffic being rerouted multiple times.\n * Nevertheless, using this method adds anonymity to your browsing habits.\n2. The dark web:\n * Special Tor links have their own domain, of a sort.\n * These links end in .Onion, and are similar to Bitcoin addresses in how they're determined. \n * Say goodbye to easy-to-remember or guess URLs.\n * These links cannot be accessed outside of the Tor network. \n * If you happen to come across one, you can try to click it, but will not be able to load the target website.\n * There are services which reroute Tor links to the clear web, allowing you to access links directly in your browser, if you so desire.\n * This (partially) erases the anonymity advantage which the Tor network would normally accord you. \n\n# A (very) brief history of Tor\n\nTor was originally developed in the 1990's by employees of the United States Naval Research Labs, and extended by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, a part of the US Department of Defense. If you are just learning about Tor, but have heard it mentioned before, this may be surprising, based on the negative light the media generally portrays it with. The original driving purpose behind Tor was protecting US intelligence communications. While I won't go into the hard numbers in this article, as it is only meant to be a high-level overview, it may be surprising to discover that approximately 60% of the Tor service is actively funded by the US Government! \n\n# Components of the Tor network\n\nAs alluded to earlier in this article, whenever you load up the Tor browser, and go to a URL, whether or not it's an active site on the Tor network, your traffic is bounced around. This section will focus on the mechanism behind these \"bounce points\", i.e., relay nodes.\n\n\n\nWhile this graphic is heavily simplified, it contains the central concepts to the Tor network which really should be fully understood by all users. I'll cover some of the implications of this most basic implementation:\n\n1. Your Tor browser connects to an entry node to get on the Tor network.\n * While this entry node is guarded from seeing your web communications, they are capable of determining your IP.\n * Does that matter to you? Probably not, but if you live in a country with an extremely oppressive government (the key target demographic for Tor, in my opinion), it's something to keep in mind.\n2. Your traffic is sent through many relay nodes.\n * The network needs a lot of volunteers to run nodes in order to keep the network strongly anonymized.\n3. Ultimately, your traffic exits from an appropriately titled \"exit relay\".\n * These are the most important nodes, in a sense, since all traffic of Tor users is no longer shielded beyond the exit node.\n * The implication of this is that volunteers should be careful to host exit nodes if they could be held liable for the web traffic by their government.\n\n# Conclusion\n\n\n\nWell you've made it to the end, so hopefully you've gained a basic enough understanding of the Tor network to put it to effective use. If you feel uneasy about any aspect I've covered, I encourage you to do your own research, especially before volunteering to help the project by posting a node.\n\n

\n\n*Disclaimer: This article is a Steemit original. Images were labeled for non-commercial reuse. Due to the superficial nature of this article, sources are not provided, but could be upon request.*", "author": "geoffrey", "parent_permlink": "security", "json_metadata": "usdsteem-btc-technical-analysis", "curator": "geoffrey", "comment_author": "ozchartart"}], "trx_in_block": 9, "op_in_trx": 1, "block": 3550129, "timestamp": "2016-07-27T04:54:36", "id": "2.17.2418781", "trx_id": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000", "virtual_op": 23029}]], [[1631, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "advice-for-fixing-a-damaged-raid-5-array", "parent_author": "", "title": "Advice for Fixing a Damaged RAID-5 array", "body": "

\nImage Source: https://www.flickr.com/photos/wwarby/11682625885\n\n# Preamble\n\nThis isn't a complete guide, more of a "things to be aware of before you run into this issue" sort of advice column. If you are looking to use RAID-5, this may be worth a read. If you've recently lost your RAID-5 array, and are looking to repair it, this guide is best used as a supplement to the many existing walkthroughs out there.\n\n# Introduction\n\nRAID arrays are touted as a great way to effortlessly backup your data on the fly, once you set them up. As long as they aren't strictly used for performance, such as RAID-0. The coolest sounding RAID array is RAID-5, which allows for 1 hard drive to fail in the presence of as many as you can plug in, despite only losing the equivalent of that drive's storage capacity (Due to the wonders of mathematics and the XOR operation). There is a darker side to RAID-5, however, which isn't commonly discussed.\n\n## The major pitfall of using RAID-5\n\nWhile you feel safe that your data is secure from one of your hard drives failing, the use of RAID-5 creates a far more insidious risk. Specifically, the potential of disks falling out of your RAID array, resulting in you losing all of your data permanently. I will discuss how I've had the misfortune of this happening on multiple occasions, despite none of the 6 hard drives in my array ever undergoing hardware failures. I hope this will give you the opportunity to learn from my mistakes, if for some reason you feel it worth attempting to use this type of RAID setup.\n\n\n\nA RAID-5 array is protected from (non-hardware related) data-loss as well as the Titanic was protected from sinking.\n\n# A cautionary tale; how I've lost my entire RAID arrayed data on multiple occasions\n\nOf course you may think it unfair of me to criticize a backup system itself when the cause of my data-loss was my own stupidity. The problem is, there's not much by way of warning for how to properly avoid damaging your RAID setup. My particular mistake was so simple, but just being aware of it may prevent you from suffering the severe data loss I have:\n\n## Do not do this!\n1. Go into BIOS\n2. Switch RAID array to SATA or AHCI\n3. Boot into Windows\n\nNow you may be thinking *"why on Earth would I ever even consider doing that?"* \n\n**GOOD! Don't!**\n\n## Exacerbating the issue\n\nBut even if you go ahead and undergo those steps, you aren't at the point yet where all of your data is gone kaput. Now at this stage, the obvious thing to do is restart, re-enable RAID in the BIOS, boot-up, and pretend like the whole kerfuffle never happened. Hell, maybe you'll get lucky, and your RAID array is magically intact, showing up as a single large hard-disk in your "My Computer". This wasn't the case for me, any of the times I've gone through this terrible debacle.\n\nWhat I see at this stage on my RAID management interface is that TWO disks have dropped out of the array. A RAID-5 array is useless without x-1 of x functioning disks, so in this situation the software is convinced your data is permanently lost. Maybe there are better ways to rebuild the array (or pop those two disks back in), but I haven't came across them before following the subsequent path to my own dismay.\n\n## This is when you start reading through guides online\n\nNow there is a lot of advice out there for recovering RAID-5 arrays. There are multiple software programs dedicated to this singular issue, some are even free. This wouldn't be much of a guide if I didn't link to them, so here is a free one that should work if you don't do what I tell you not to do shortly: http://www.freeraidrecovery.com/ (This is not an endorsement; I can't get the software to work for reasons that will become clear shortly).\n\nThese guides typically suggest some counter-intuitive steps: Delete your existing array with the dropped disks, make a new array with the same disks (IN THE SAME ORDER!), and magically all of your problems are solved. You might need to run [TestDisk](http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk) after this (This is an endorsement, TestDisk is awesome for so many hard drive related problems!). Maybe your problems will be solved at this stage. \n\n## My problems weren't solved\n\nWhat these guides must not mention is that if you use **Intel Rapid Storage Technology** software, you're royally boned. What happens when you recreate your array, even if you've put the correct sector size, disk order, and all of the other parameters completely correctly, this problem cannot be fixed if you have this software installed. **Your array will instantly be wiped upon detection!** This process is called "initialization", and as far as I can tell involves formatting the disks, deleting the MBR and any copies of the partition table. Your data is gone forever at this stage, even if you interrupt the process at 1%.\n\n# Learn from my mistake\n\n\n\nI haven't been able to test this process, since every time my RAID array has failed I've gone through the same steps, and believe me I feel horrible about it. Nevertheless, here are the steps I think will work best if you insist on keeping the Intel Rapid Storage Technology software installed.\n\n## You can try this, but caveat emptor\n* Only follow this guide once you've lost 2 or more disks from your RAID-5 array\n1. Delete your RAID array using your management software\n2. Start Windows (assuming your boot disk is not part of your array. If it is, wow, that was a really bad idea! 20/20 hindsight, though...)\n3. Run your favorite RAID-5 recovery program\n4. Recover the data to an Image file on some other disk not part of your array\n5. Build a new array, using the original parameters, and try the test-disk method again anyway, just for fun, don't expect much\n6. Restore the image to your brand new initialized array if your test disk recovery failed.\n\n# Conclusion\nWell, there you have it, a comprehensive look at why RAID-5 is the devil incarnate a cheap way to build a redundant storage solution. I'll be happy to dispense further advice for your particular situation in the comments in dealing with your pet RAID-5 array. Or advice on putting one together (for your own sanity, please don't).\n\n\n

"48b947b0c302b2e6082afd4f0bf6b16192fa971f", "virtual_op": 12813}]], [[2034, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "new-web-app-tells-you-how-much-curation-reward-you-will-earn-provides-api", "parent_author": "", "title": "New Web App Tells You How Much Curation Reward You Will Earn + Provides API", "body": "# http://steemit-estimator.herokuapp.com/\n\n## Introduction\n\nI've noticed that the relationship between how much Steem Power I hold, and how much reward I earn for voting is not obvious, and seems to be a non-linear function. To make it much easier to figure out how acquiring more Steem will give you more curation rewards, I've built a **fully open source web app**, and deployed it on Heroku, to address this problem.\n\n

\n\n## Description\n\nThe app uses a formula derived from this post to determine how a change in your balance will affect your average daily curation reward: https://steemit.com/steem/@killerstorm/why-steem-curation-reward-is-needlessly-unfair-and-how-to-fix-it .\n\nThe formula uses Poloniex's ticker to get both the price of Steem in BTC, and BTC in USD to create the estimate. It updates every time you click a button or refresh the page.\n\n## Assumptions\n\n* You consistently vote every day, maintaining a consistent voting power\n* The prices of BTC and STEEM do not change substantially in the two year period it takes to cash-out\n * I realize this is a bit far-fetched, but the reward is also cited in STEEM, allowing you to account for the change in value yourself\n* The increase (or decrease) in voting power that comes with powering up is in fact proportional to the square of the percent change (as stated in the linked article)\n* If you vote on articles early, this assumes they consistently become popular at the same rate on an average day\n * This would most likely result in the estimation being low if you have a very good day\n\n## How it works\n\nIt's a simple Flask app which I personally created from scratch today. As a bonus, it contains an **API for getting account balance** (http://steemit-estimator.herokuapp.com/account_balance/@name), **daily reward** (http://steemit-estimator.herokuapp.com/daily_reward/@name), and the estimate **directly** for a given *new* amount of Steem Power (http://steemit-estimator.herokuapp.com/approximate_reward/@name/10000), though this only works for account who are already receiving some positive reward.\n\n## Suggested usage\n\nThe most accurate prediction for how much reward you receive would be for you to enter a user's name with a balance you are planning on acquiring. If this user has similar voting habits to you, you should be fairly confident that's how much you'll earn in a day (remember, assuming constant STEEM and BTC price).\n\n## Planned features\n\n* The next update will graph, for a range of values, how much you will earn from curation based on how much Steem you hold\n * This will allow you to optimize the amount of Steem to purchase without trial-and-error calculations.\n* The Interface will be cleaned up, and made to look nicer\n\n## TL;DR\n![](http://s2.quickmeme.com/img/79/79af6b3bc5b23131ace1d835c402fa444ebd7cfc574c6b040665280337e74d7e.jpg)\n\nI welcome suggestions in the comments. I'll be happy to provide any help if anything needs clarification.\n\n\n

"2.17.3067060", "trx_id": "e31499d94ec01652ab4c5dd9981a61735673fcc5", "virtual_op": 24819}]], [[2284, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "determine-how-much-sp-you-need-to-retire-on-curator-earnings", "parent_author": "", "title": "Determine How Much SP You Need to Retire On Curator Earnings", "body": "**There is a lot of uncertainty around the curation reward.** In short, 25% of a posts rewards are divided up among curators at payout, with curators who voted early receiving a larger portion, and the total receive weighted by each curator's Steem Power. This is all done in a non-transparent way. \n\n**My goal is to simplify the expected earnings consistent curators will receive**, based on the curation bonus's they've gotten over the previous week. To help determine how much Powering Up will help a particular curator, I've build a webapp that estimates the effect of a change in Steem Power balance, available here: https://steemit-estimator.herokuapp.com/submit_form (For more instructions you can see my announcement at [steem.com/@geoffrey](https://steemit.com/steemit/@geoffrey/new-web-app-tells-you-how-much-curation-reward-you-will-earn-provides-api)).\n
\n![pexels-photo6739d.jpg](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/07/31/pexels-photo6739d.jpg)\n\n# Am I ready to commit to Curation?\n\n**In order to determine if you really can retire based just on your earnings**, it's fairly straight-forward to determine what those earnings will be after a large power up (or power down if you wish). Just enter your username, and an amount of Steem Power you intend to hold, and hit the 'calculate' button.\n\n**If your goal is to retire with a set daily earnings**, let's say $100 a day from curation rewards, then try increasing the amount of Steem Power you will hold until you hit that number. In my case, while holding ~1802 Steem Power, I earn 78 cents a day in rewards. I would need roughly 22,000 Steem Power to be achieve the earnings in this example. What that means is I would have to go on an exchange, and purchase 20,198 Steem, and power all of it up, in order to reach those target earnings. At current prices, that's a little over $48,000, which is an unrealistic amount for me, unfortunately. Your situation may be better, maybe you are gifted at picking winners with your votes. Or maybe you've earned a rather large author reward for a few posts, and need a much smaller increment of Steem Power to reach your target earnings.\n
\n# So that's it, just Power Up and I'm set for life?\n\n**Keep in mind the assumptions listed in the announcement**, and that Steem Power becomes diluted every day at a large (but decreasing over the next few years) rate. Those of us who are mostly Powered Up are shielded from this, but if you're holding strictly Steem, you are losing a larger share of the Steem pie as time goes by, with people constantly powering down.\n\n![beach](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/07/31/beach-382488_960_720bbca7.jpg)\n
\n# Sounds great, sign me up!\n\n**Okay, just buy yourself as much Steem as you need on one of the exchanges, and power it up!** Everybody who does this is helping the network in a multitude of ways, not least of which is taking Steem off of the market, thereby raising the price through added scarcity. I personally thank you for that!\n\n**Just bear in mind, you will be receiving weekly payments for 2 years when you need to cash out** . My advice is to acquire as much Steem as you need now, as long as it reasonably fits in your budget, and wait a month or two before you start powering down enough of your gains to not affect your total \"retirement plan\". Of course, with the 2 year payout, you have to believe Steemit will remain stable, or grow, in the long term. I firmly believe this is the case, and have bought more than half of the Steem currently in my wallet.\n
\n![votinga13dd.png](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/07/31/votinga13dd.png)\n\n## And remember: vote early and vote often!\n\n\n

Just keep this list in mind, if you don't already know any of these rapid-fire tips, and you'll be earning the big bucks on #photography in no time!\n
\n1. **Set your resolution to the maximum your device can record**\n * Turn off compression and use RAW if it's an option\n * Flash storage is cheap. I mean *cheeeeeap* so don't be stingy with it!\n * Your imager was designed to take photos at the maximal possible resolution, by setting it to use a smaller image-size, you're wasting the efforts of hard-working engineers!\n![](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/08/01/birch-yellow-pollen-closeup-image-256x2562bb4b.png)\n(What is this photo supposed to be? Maybe we'd know if they hadn't used such a low resolution!)\n2. **Avoid blurriness - specifically through camera shake**\n * If available, use a tripod or monopod\n * If not, place your camera on a hard surface and hold it down with one hand while taking a photo\n * Turn on image stabilization\n * Set a maximum shutter-speed, i.e., exposure time, if possible, such as 1/30th of a second (more on this in a follow up post)\n * Use a higher ISO if necessary (though this will add graininess and loss of depth)\n * Newer high end cameras are good at high ISO low noise images though. Isn't technological advancement swell?\n![](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/08/01/6322890109_c500dfd79f_b4258d.jpg)\nImage source: https://www.flickr.com/photos/deargdoom57/6322890109\n(Okay, it actually works for this photo, but we can't all spin our shaky-hands into decent photos with god-tier camera control)\n3. **Always use the flash - even in broad daylight**\n * This tip is more of my personal opinion than a hard rule, though\n * I plan to devote a whole post to using flash, but this article assumes you are just using your device's built-in \"fill-flash\"\n * Some may argue that using flash can decrease the amount of depth to a photo, but I prefer a flatter photo to an underexposed face, in the case of a portrait where that's the whole point!\n![](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/08/01/ebano-en-el-parque7fc15.jpg)\n(Again, this isn't a particularly bad photo, but I don't personally like the shadow over a large portion of the subject's face)\n4. **As a follow-up, make sure the sun isn't in the frame!**\n * It will completely wash out your subject, even in the presence of bright flash\n * This rule also applies to artificial light sources, and extremely bright reflections\n![](https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/08/01/backlight-1007214_960_720a03c5.jpg)\n(This is more of an intended lens-flare effect than a bad sun-framing-joby, but still I personally dislike it and feel it illustrates my point)\n\nAnd that's it! Now you're ready to go out there and take photos people won't have to look at with patronizing disapproval. If there's interest, I plan to extend this series with tips on composition, manual photography settings, how to use more advanced equipment (with a focus on external flashes), and how to create cool effects (with the camera directly, and through post-processing), and whatever else strikes my fancy.\n\n*Disclaimer: This is an original SteemIt post. All photos were provided either with no attribution necessary, or attribution is given beneath the picture.", "author": "geoffrey", "parent_permlink": "photography", "json_metadata": "{\"tags\":[\"photography\",\"howto\",\"technique\",\"cameras\",\"photos\"],\"image\":[\"https://www.steemimg.com/images/2016/08/01/birch-yellow-pollen-closeup-image-256x2562bb4b.png\"]}"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 3693826, "timestamp": "2016-08-01T05:30:09", "id": "2.17.3117193", "trx_id": "a11d13fda37248824027c19b017941f4ed5d274d", "virtual_op": 10196}]], [[2428, {"op": ["vote", {"voter": "geoffrey", "weight": 10000, "permlink": "take-better-photos-a-series-of-tips-for-aspiring-digital-photogs-part-1", "author": "geoffrey"}], "trx_in_block": 0, "op_in_trx": 1, "block": 3693826, "timestamp": "2016-08-01T05:30:09", "id": "2.17.3117194", "trx_id": "a11d13fda37248824027c19b017941f4ed5d274d", "virtual_op": 10197}]], [[2429, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "re-take-better-photos-a-series-of-tips-for-aspiring-digital-photogs-part-1-20160801t053013", "parent_author": "geoffrey", "title": "Flesch Kincaid Grade Level", "body": "Hi! "re-r4fken-bitfinex-hacked-breaking-20160802t204422131z", "json_metadata": "{\"tags\":[\"news\"]}"}], "trx_in_block": 2, "op_in_trx": 0, "block": 3743601, "timestamp": "2016-08-02T23:07:42", "id": "2.17.3314668", "trx_id": "c92af91e408514cc316b002cd929f061bc6ca918", "virtual_op": 13936}]], [[2751, {"op": ["comment", {"permlink": "steem-mining-comprehensive-guide", "parent_author": "", "title": "Steem Mining - Comprehensive Guide", "body": "\n
\nFinding pertinent information concerning mining Steem is a non-trivial issue. Realize that only 1% of the Steem Power reward goes to miners, so it's not the most cost-effective way to gain Steem. And then there's the issue of not being able to transfer or sell it without having to trickle it out over two years. Nevertheless, there's something satisfying about knowing your computers are working for you, and watching the hashes fly by.\n\n# How To Set Up Your Miner\n\nThe exact setup for a miner depends mainly on your operating system. I haven't personally tried Mac OSX, so I can't comment on that, but I know for a fact that both Windows and Linux are capable of mining Steem. I haven't noticed any differences in performance across operating system, but I haven't controlled for many factors, including number of processing cores, speed of cores, generation of processor, amount of RAM, etc, so your results may vary.\n\n1. Install or compile the mining software\n * **Windows Mining**\n * Despite claims to the contrary, it's possible to mine directly in Windows without setting up a Virtual Machine\n * Thanks to work by @btscube you can mine in Windows with precompiled binaries\n * Announcement: https://steemit.com/steem/@bitcube/steem-windows-wallet-and-miner-v0-12-2\n * Release: https://github.com/btscube/steem/releases/\n * I've tried compiling from source, but there's a problem with compiling boost on Windows: It's a huge headache, mainly\n * The binary at the link works fine, though\n * **Linux Mining**\n * By far the most common method of mining\n * This process is easier to set up, and better documented\n * Source Code: https://github.com/steemit/steem.git\n * I'll give instructions for compilation from the source if you're using this method, because there are only a few steps and it could be instructive\n * **Mac Mining**\n * Probably this will work: https://steemit.com/osx/@metasyn/fix-steemd-on-osx-homebrew-error-fix\n * Alternatively you can run a VM and install Ubuntu, similar to Windows' guides suggestions\n\n## How to Compile Steemd and cli_wallet\nThe first step, if you're using Ubuntu 14.04 or early, is to get Boost set up properly. Steemd requires a specific version of Boost which is more recent than the default repositories provide. This may also be the case with 16.01, but I haven't tried compiling there.\n\nBefore following any of these instructions, I encourage you to think about what each line actually does, and don't be afraid to ask questions if you're not sure. It's better to sound silly than to break your computer.\n\n### Updating to Boost-1.60\nThe easy way to update boost is to avoid compiling it entirely, in my opinion, and to just add a repository that is already hosting it. Then it's a matter of simply updating the list of available packages, and installing the correct version (Steem wants 1.60):\n\n**Enter these commands into a terminal:**\n```\necho 'deb http://cz.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu yakkety main universe' | sudo tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list\nsudo apt-get update\nsudo apt-get install libboost1.60-all-dev -y\nsudo apt auto-remove -y\n```\n\nJust four lines of commands, no wait for compilation, hell no wait for tar to extract 30,000 files, no having to install to the correct path, and no need to manually remove the conflicting default version; no muss, no fuss.\n\n### Compiling *steemd* and *cli_wallet*\nFinally we're at the most pivotal step, compiling the *steemd* client. This process may take some time, possibly upwards of 15 minutes, so have patience while it completes.\n\n**Enter these commands into a terminal:**\n```\nsudo apt-get install -y cmake git doxygen libssl-dev libsecp256k1-dev libncurses5-dev libreadline-dev tmux\ngit clone http://github.com/steemit/steem.git\ncd steem\ngit submodule update --init --recursive\ncmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DENABLE_CONTENT_PATCHING=OFF -DLOW_MEMORY_NODE=ON\n\ncores=$(nproc)\nmake -j$cores\n```\n\nThis will use all of your processing cores to compile files simultaneously. You can specify how many cores you want to use by providing a number, e.g., \"make -j3\" would use at most three processing threads. Your computer may hang during the compilation, in which case I'd recommend trying again without the '-j' flag in the command. While it's easier to just use 'make -j' directly, I've had that crash more often during compilation than specifying the number of cores on my PC.\n\nNow I don't see it mentioned anywhere, but I believe the *low memory node* flag implies that your node can only be used for mining. If you have that set, you won't be able to run a full node, which is necessary to become a witness. This also means Steem will require far less memory. With the low memory blockchain already being >1.5GB, this is probably in your best interest. I'd appreciate feedback on the validity of this point, however.\n\n## Adding the Client to the User Path\nNow personally, I like to put everything in my root folder, and work from there. If you're not like me, and like to be tidier, follow these instructions so you can run 'steemd' from anywhere\n\n```\nsudo cp ~/steem/programs/steemd/steemd ~/steem/programs/cli_wallet/cli_wallet /usr/bin\n```\n\n## Final Steps - Slow Method (No worries about skipping this part)\n\nYou didn't skip it? Cool, this should give you a more through understanding of what's going on. Or maybe not, maybe you're just wasting time going through this section, hell I feel like I wasted a lot of time just writing it!\n\nEnter these commands:\n```\ncd\nmkdir witness_node_data_dir\nnano witness_node_data_dir/config.ini\n```\n\n### Setting up *config.ini*\nNow this is where things get interactive. You can use VIM, EMACS, GEDIT, whatever you feel most comfortable with for this part. We're going to set up our miners. Here's my config.ini, just replace the `witness=` and `miner=` with your account's. I'll give more detail on that at the end of setup.\n\nCut and paste this text into *config.ini*\n```\n# P2P nodes to connect to on startup (may specify multiple times)\n# seed-node =\nseed-node = 52.38.66.234:2001\nseed-node = 52.37.169.52:2001\nseed-node = 52.26.78.244:2001\nseed-node = 192.99.4.226:2001\nseed-node = 46.252.27.1:1337\nseed-node = 81.89.101.133:2001\nseed-node = 52.4.250.181:39705\nseed-node = steemd.pharesim.me:2001\nseed-node = seed.steemed.net:2001\nseed-node = steem.clawmap.com:2001\nseed-node = seed.steemwitness.com:2001\nseed-node = steem-seed1.abit-more.com:2001\n\n# Set an API to be publicly available, may be specified multiple times\npublic-api = database_api login_api\n\n# Plugin(s) to enable, may be specified multiple times\nenable-plugin = witness account_history\n\n# Track market history by grouping orders into buckets of equal size measured in seconds specified as a JSON array of numbers\nbucket-size = [15,60,300,3600,86400]\n\n# How far back in time to track history for each bucket size, measured in the number of buckets (default: 5760)\nhistory-per-size = 5760\n\n# Enable block production, even if the chain is stale.\nenable-stale-production = false\n\n# Percent of witnesses (0-99) that must be participating in order to produce blocks\nrequired-participation = false\n\n# name of witness controlled by this node (e.g. initwitness )\n# witness =\nwitness=\"geoffrey\"\n\n# name of miner and its private key (e.g. [\"account\",\"WIF PRIVATE KEY\"] )\n# miner =\nminer=[\"geoffrey\",\"geoffrey's ACTIVE key\"]\n\n# Number of threads to use for proof of work mining\n# mining-threads =\nmining-threads = 8\n\n# WIF PRIVATE KEY to be used by one or more witnesses or miners\n# private-key =\nprivate-key = geoffrey's ACTIVE key\n\n# declare an appender named \"stderr\" that writes messages to the console\n[log.console_appender.stderr]\nstream=std_error\n\n# declare an appender named \"p2p\" that writes messages to p2p.log\n[log.file_appender.p2p]\nfilename=logs/p2p/p2p.log\n# filename can be absolute or relative to this config file\n\n# route any messages logged to the default logger to the \"stderr\" logger we\n# declared above, if they are info level are higher\n[logger.default]\nlevel=warn\nappenders=stderr\n\n# route messages sent to the \"p2p\" logger to the p2p appender declared above\n[logger.p2p]\nlevel=warn\nappenders=p2p\n```\n\nWhere `mining-threads = ` should be set to your number of processing threads.\n\nNow, the witness and miner are the important attributes here. You want to get your active key for your account from https://steemit.com/@geoffrey/permissions where you'll need to login and click \"show key\". The key should start with a \"5\", not \"STM\", which is your public key. I've also filled in the `private-key=` with that same key (**no quotes around it**), but I believe that's completely redundant and unnecessary.\n\n### Finally, We Can Start Mining\n\nThis time, we're going to start a tmux session which stays open as long as you're mining. That way, if you close your terminal window, it won't interrupt the mining. This is just a one-liner: \n`tmux new-session -s steem-mine '~/steemd --rpc-endpoint'`\n\nYou should see some stuff happening, and it should start talking about how many blocks it's downloaded every 10,000. Right now there's nearly 4,000,000 so it will take some time. If you're satisfied it's doing its thing, hit `control-b + d` to detach from tmux. That's holding `control` while hitting `b`, letting go of `control` and hitting `d` in quick succession. Confusing, I know. If you screw up somehow, hit `control-c` to get out of any interactivity. If you get pissed off enough, keep hitting `control-c` until you kill tmux dead.\n\n## Final Steps - Fast Method\n\nIf you followed the instructions up to here, you will start downloading the blockchain from other nodes. This is a slow process. You can speed things up considerably by downloading a recent snapshot of the blockchain. To accomplish this, we use @steemychicken1's updated snapshot: \n\n```\ncd\nwget http://www.steemitup.eu/witness_node_data_dir.tar.gz\ntar xvzf witness_node_data_dir.tar.gz\n```\n\nThe download should only take about 20 minutes on a 1MB/s connection. This method includes a pre-customized 'config.ini', so edit that after you extract the folder to add your miners. An easy way of dong this is with the \"append\" command: \n\n```\ncd ~/witness_node_data_dir\necho 'witness=geoffrey' >> config.ini\necho 'miner=[\"geoffrey\",\"Active key\"]' >> config.ini\necho 'mining-threads=8' >> config.ini\n```\n\nBut be **careful** with the nested single and double quotes. Once the blockchain is setup and everything is configured, we can start mining as above: \n`tmux new-session -s steem-mine '~/steemd --rpc-endpoint --replay-blockchain'`.\n\nYou only need to replay the blockchain your first time using that bootstrapped blockchain. You can just run \n`tmux new-session -s steem-mine '~/steemd --rpc-endpoint` when starting again.\n\n## Phew, that was a lot longer than \"a few steps\"\n\nMy bad. Once it's all written down it does seem somewhat extensive. Hopefully if you've got to this point, you can take solace in the fact that your computer is now earning you Steem Power! If not, well, comment and I'll try to help you debug. Or go on http://steemit.chat and join #mining for further support.\n\n# How to mine to multiple addresses\n\nWhy would you want to do this? If you're fortunate enough to find a block (CONGRATULATIONS!), you are forced to wait about an hour, in what's called a queue, for you to get paid for that block, and to get a chance to mine again with that miner. During that time, your computer will sit idle, unless you setup additional accounts to mine to during that downtime. These accounts are prioritized by alphabetical order, so one easy solution is to take your real username, and append increments to the end for each extra queued miner.\n\nThis part is easy, it's the as in the previous steps:\n\n```\ncd ~/witness_node_data_dir\n\n# Repeat for each extra miner\necho 'witness=geoffrey-01' >> config.ini\necho 'miner=[\"geoffrey-01\",\"new mining key\"]' >> config.ini\necho 'mining-threads=8' >> config.ini\n```\n\nPersonally, I just reuse my ACTIVE key for my main account for each miner. Though this suggests you should go to extra effort to keep your *config.ini* secure and unseen by potentially malicious actors.\n\n## How do I know if my miner found a block? When can it start mining again?\n\nThe easiest way to monitor this, that I know of, is to visit your page on steemd: http://steemd.com/@account and you should see \"account found a pow\" on your log. You can then visit http://steemd.com/witnesses and watch your name slowly climb up the \"Miner-witness queue\" on the right-hand side. It takes almost a minute to move up one spot, and the queue is generally 100+ entries long, so you can see why you'll probably want at least two miners available so you're not just sitting there waiting for work to start again.\n\n# How to mine across multiple computers\n\nNow this is where I cannot claim confidence in my solution. I would like to propose the best way of doing this, and would appreciate feedback from anyone who is doing this. The main issue comes from the fact that **if** you set the same witness on two different computers, and **if** you mine a block simultaneously on both, you will forfeit your **entire account balance** to anybody else who notices what you've just done. Harsh, right!?\n\nThe main issue is that it's **hard** to get mined Steem Power out of an account. I think you need to have earned quite a bit, and wait a while, before you can power down. This will then require waiting two years to get the full balance. Because of this, I would personally prefer to always be able to mine to my main account when it's not minting. Here is an illustration of how I propose to do this, but due to the extensive risk involved I haven't tried this solution across my three computers:\n\n* Computer 1's *config.ini* excerpt:\n\n```\nwitness = \"geoffrey\"\nminer = [\"geoffrey\",\"Active key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-01\",\"geoffrey key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-02\",\"geoffrey key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-03\",\"geoffrey key\"]\n```\n
\n* Computer 2's *config.ini* excerpt:\n\n```\nwitness = \"geoffrey-01\"\nminer = [\"geoffrey\",\"Active key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-01\",\"geoffrey key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-02\",\"geoffrey key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-03\",\"geoffrey key\"]\n```\n
\n* Computer 3's *config.ini* excerpt:\n\n```\nwitness = \"geoffrey-02\"\nminer = [\"geoffrey\",\"Active key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-01\",\"geoffrey key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-02\",\"geoffrey key\"]\nminer = [\"geoffrey-03\",\"geoffrey key\"]\n```\n
\nSimple, right? None of the computers use the same witness, but they all have the same miners. One of the miners never even serves as a witness, in fact. Is this all of this above board? Will this allow me to optimize reward allocation across accounts? \n\n*Do the mining rewards even go to the miner, or do they go to the witness?*\n\nThese questions are best answered by someone who has successfully mined in this fashion. So, I look to you, the readers, for an answer to this question.\n\n# Connecting with the *cli_wallet*\n\nIf you've noticed, we always use the '--rpc-endpoint' option with steemd. This is so we can connect with the *cli_wallet* for monitoring. You can specify the ip and port to connect with in the *config.ini* [if you so wish](https://steem.io/documentation/how-use-wallet-via-json-rpc-over-http/), but I prefer to let the steemd handle choosing a port for me.\n\nHowever, this article is long enough without me documenting how to use the *cli_wallet*. I hardly ever use it, anyway, since most of the end-user stuff is accessible through steemit.com.\n\n\n\n# Thanks for making it all the way to the end!\n\nI hope you found this article fascinating, or if it was in fact mind-numbingly dull, at least maybe somewhat educational.\n\n\n

"parent_author": "", "title": "Steemit Whale Sounds", "body": "## There's a lot of talk about Steemit's whales, and how big an influence they have on the content of the site.\n\nIn an effort to quantify the contributions of some of the largest whales, I've put together a list of Cetacae and the accounts which they represent, along with a clip of their various songs.\n\n \n
\n\n\n# Blue Whale\n \n@ned: With >3M Steem Power, by far the largest account.\n\n# Fin Whale\n\n@dan, @blocktrades: At >2M Steem Power each, still impressively sized accounts.\n\n# Right Whale\n\n@jamesc, @ben, @berniesanders: At around 1.8M Steem Power each, these are relatively massive accounts.\n\n# Sperm Whale\n\n@smooth, @val-a, @dantheman: At <1.5M Steem Power each, these are still some serious contenders.\n\nHaving covered accounts 2-10, I think that summarizes the size of the true Steemit heavy hitters pretty well. \n\n## I'd now like to give a shout-out to the more earthly creatures among us\n\n# Dolphins\n\nPlayful and loud, a pretty apt description for a lot of the more mid-sized accounts on Steemit.\n\n# Minnows\n\nOf such little importance there are no recordings of the sounds they make anywhere I've looked. Don't worry, though, there are still a lot more of us than any of the other types of accounts listed!\n
\nSo, which type of account are you? If you're a whale, which kind of whale would you like to be? Let me know in the comments!\n\n\n\nMost images and sounds' source: List of whale vocalizations.
